article:
In continuum mechanics, the 'finite strain theory'âalso called 'large strain
theory', or 'large deformation theory'âdeals with deformations in which both
rotations and strains are arbitrarily large, i.e. invalidates the assumptions
inherent in infinitesimal strain theory. In this case, the undeformed and
deformed configurations of the continuum are significantly different and a
clear distinction has to be made between them. This is commonly the case with
elastomers, plastically-deforming materials and other fluids and biological
soft tissue.
headings: Transformation of a surface and volume element
Polar decomposition of the deformation gradient tensor
Physical interpretation of the finite strain tensor
